_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Rupture disk inspection/replacement on all reactors

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0	RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Chemline facility has comprehensive safety and process training programs to reduce the risk of accidental releases and emergencies.  Should a release or emergency occur, Chemline has implemented an Emergency Action and Contingency Plan (EACP) as well as coordination with outside agencies, such as the St. Louis City LEPC and St. Louis City Fire Department, to ensure there is emergency response coverage 24 hours  7 days per week.


2.0	PROCESS DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

At this location, Chemline manufactures and produces polyurethane and polyurea coatings as well as rigid and flexible polyurethane foams.  The NAICS code for the primary process at the facility is 325211, Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing.

Chemline has one regulated substance under 40 CFR 68:  Toluene Diisocyanate (CAS No. 26471-62-5) contained in various raw materials and stored in 55-gallon drums.  Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) is used as a reactant in the production of the coatings and foams.

The TDI threshold for triggering applicability to 40 CFR 68 is 10,000 pounds. The quantity of TDI stored on-site is approximately 73,000 pounds.  Thus, 40 CFR 68 is applicable to the Chemline plant in St. Louis, MO.


3.0	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Chemline is not subject to the OSHA PSM program for TDI or other chemical processes.  The processing of TDI at the facility falls under the RMP Program Level 2 prevention program. 

There are several aspects of the TDI prevention program that are key:

1. 	Area TDI monitors are strategically placed to allow for prompt detection, shutdown and emergency response if a leak occurs.
2. 	TDI drums are stored in several different areas of the facility to reduce the amount that could be released if an incident were to occur in any one area.  
3.  	The plant maintains good training, certification, and employee awareness o

f operating procedures.


4.0	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The review of the facilitys accident history includes the following range of dates:  November 26, 2019  January 2, 2024. Within this timeframe, there have been no accidental releases applicable to the criteria under 40 CFR 68.42(a).


5.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The employees of Chemline will not respond to releases of TDI at the facility.  The facility has developed an EACP to address all types of emergencies which could occur at the facility.  The plan includes key management personnel and their roles along with critical phone numbers.  Each type of emergency identified lists actions to be taken along with evacuation procedures.  The facility is included in St. Louis City LEPCs community emergency response plan. The St. Louis City Fire Department will be contacted along with a contracted spill response company if emergency response is needed.  The closest Fire Department Engine Company is located one block away from the facility, and regular walk-through tours are coordinated with crew members to familiarize them with the layout, access points, and key chemical process/storage areas of the facility.

6.0	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility is in the process of installing a new TDI process which will utilize storage tanks within containment structures, closed piping systems, automation, and safety devices such as alarms and interlocks for process control and mitigation.  This RMP will be updated and resubmitted when this change goes into effect.
